title.rendered: Lunar Calendar 2022: when does the Moon change phase |  Life

content.rendered:
What is a lunar calendar? When does the phase change occur? With the 2022 Lunar Calendar you will be able to know exactly how the Moon looks from Earth, any day of the year.

Humans have been fascinated by the Moon since prehistoric times.. Some anthropologists argue that it has been one of the catalysts of human evolution: Looking at the Moon, Humanity began to wonder.

What is that in the sky? Why does it change places? How can I get there? These questions motivated many human beings to follow the path of science.

It is not strange that Humanity’s first calendars, dating from 8,000 years ago, were lunar. And it’s the reason that the original months lasted 29 dayshow long it takes one lunar cycle.

What would happen if there was no Moon?

This cycle is divided into four phases.and for millennia it was used to plant crops, to calculate the birth of children, or to meet other people, close businesses, and other events.

Some of these situations are still ruled by the Moon, but most people go to the Lunar Calendar 2022 out of curiosity, to find out when our satellite changes phase, or when is the best time to photograph it.

As we have mentioned, the Moon has 4 phases: New moon, first quarter, full moon, and last quarter. Although there are several subphases in between.

In 2022, as explained by our colleague Daniel Cáceres in Business Insider, the moon will have 12 full cycles, and half another.

This is the most common situation, because the calendar has one more day than the lunar months, as it is coordinated with the time it takes for the Earth to revolve around the Sun.

These are the four phases of the moonand how to distinguish them:

  • new moon (or new moon): In this phase the Moon is barely visible, because the face that always faces the Earth is not illuminated by the Sun. And we can only see it when the sun reflects light on it.
  • first quarter: The right side of the Moon is illuminated in the northern hemisphere, and the other way around in the southern one.
  • full moon (or full moon): It is the most spectacular, because the Sun illuminates it completely, and we can see it completely.
  • last quarter: we can only see its left side illuminated in the northern hemisphere (as if it were the letter C), and vice versa in the southern hemisphere.

As we have mentioned, each lunar cycle lasts just over 29 days.
